bibl.title: Letter from [John J. Moran] to Harold W. Jones, August 22, 1939

div1.p: [Moran] seeks to correct the misidentification of himself in a group photograph of the Hospital Corps Detachment at Columbia Barracks.

div1.head: Letter from [John J. Moran] to Harold W. Jones, August 22, 1939
div1.opener:
Havana, Aug. 22, 1939.
Col. Harold W. Jones,
Medical Corps, U. S. Army,
The Librarian,
Army Medical Library,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Col. Jones:
div1.p:
I beg to refer you to Negative No. 65638, being a group
or Detachment picture of the Hospital Corps Detachment at Columbia
Barracks, Quemados, Cuba (Camp Columbia), Post Hospital, purport-
ed to have been taken in September, 1900.

Through the courtesy of General Jefferson R. Kean, Medical
Corps, U. S. Army, Retired, I received a copy of the photograph or
picture under reference. Imagine my surprise to find myself listed
as No. 15 in the picture. On April 27th, 1937, I wrote to General
Albert E. Truby, U. S. Army, Retired, pointing out THAT I WAS NOT AND
COULD NOT the man identified as such. Neither could I identify the
man to whom Number 15 was assigned. I did, however, identify No. 14
as Private Warren Gladsden Jernegan (not Warren J. Jernegan as shown on
the list), pointing out to General Truby that error also. I now take
it that General Truby has not revised the list and that it has remained
as originally submitted by him. I am not concerned, of course, with
correction in the case of Jernegan (shown on the list as Pvt. Kneisley)
but the error with reference to myself should be corrected, subject of
course to approval of General Truby. General Truby, in a letter he
wrote me on May 22, 1937, admitted that he listed me as No. 15, based
on opinion of England (No. 24) and Sontag (No. 41).

head.hi: R E S U M E N

list.item:
(1) No. 15 in the picture IS NOT JOHN J. MORAN, either as a civilian
nor as a soldier.

(2) From date of my arrival in Cuba until I was discharged from the
service on July 2, 1900, my rank was that of Actg. Hosp. Steward.

(3) I was a civilian clerk at Gen. Fitzhugh Lee's Headquarters in
September, 1900, when the picture was taken.

div1.p:
I am writing to you about this matter because you recently
sent a copy of the picture under reference to Mr. Joseph C. Furnas
for use in connection with an article entitled “DEATH IN A MIRROR”,
published in The Saturday Evening Post on August 5th. On the list
accompanying that picture, I was still shown as No. 15. The Art
Editor of The SATEVEPOST sent it to me for verification. If you have
read the article referred to, please note that the photo of me as I
am today does not bear the slightest resemblance to No. 15 in the
picture. I am sure that the Army Medical Library would not wittingly
supply incorrect information in any such matter as that at issue, nor
would General Truby either. Thanking you for correcting the error,
I remain,
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, Address: John J. Moran,
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.,
Avenida Menocal Nos. 455-457,
Havana, Cuba.
